SubTopics: Investigate how organisms and populations in an ecosystem depend on and may compete for biotic factors such as food and abiotic factors such as quantity of light, water, range of temperatures, or soil composition.
Content: Immediately after a forest fire, the primary consumers in the area will compete most for Which biotic factor?

A.Choice: Food

Key.Rationale: A biotic factor is a living part of an ecosystem. Primary consumers obtain energy by consuming plants. Plants are living, so plants are considered biotic.
Space is not a living part of the ecosystem. Space is an abiotic factor.
Oxygen is not a living part of the ecosystem. Oxygen is an abiotic factor.

D.Choice: Sunlight

Key.Rationale: Sunlight is not a living part of the ecosystem. Sunlight is an abiotic factor.

SubTopics: Investigate and describe applications of Newton's three laws of motion such as in vehicle restraints, sports activities, amusement park rides, Earth's tectonic activities, and rocket launches.
Content: A steel ball is at one end of a box that is moving forward as shown. The box suddenly stops.
problems/TX21G8S/media/2a.jpg
According to Newton's first law, what happens to the steel ball just after the box stops?

F.Choice: Because of friction, the ball continues rolling forward at the same speed.

Key.Rationale: Friction is a force that acts in the opposite direction of the motion and will cause changes in speed and/or direction. Friction would cause the ball to slow down, not to continue rolling forward at the same speed.

G.Choice: Because of friction, the ball rolls forward at an increased speed.

Key.Rationale: Friction would cause the ball to slow down, not roll forward at an increasing speed.

H.Choice: Because of inertia, the ball continues rolling forward at the same speed.

Key.Rationale: Inertia is the tendency of an object to resist changes in its motion. Inertia causes the ball to continue moving in the same direction and at the same speed.

J.Choice: Because of inertia, the ball rolls forward at an increased speed.

Key.Rationale: Inertia causes the ball to continue the motion it had already, not to increase in speed.

SubTopics: Investigate how evidence of chemical reactions indicates that new substances with different properties are formed and how that relates to the law of conservation of mass.
Analyze data to formulate reasonable explanations, communicate valid conclusions supported by the data, and predict trends.
Content: Students mixed two liquids in a beaker and listed their observations.
problems/TX21G8S/media/3a.jpg
Based on these observations, which statement contains the best evidence that a chemical reaction occurred?

A.Choice: There is a change in shape.

Key.Rationale: A change in shape is not evidence that a chemical reaction occurred, but it can be evidence that a physical change occurred.

B.Choice: There is a change in volume.

Key.Rationale: A change in volume is not evidence that a chemical reaction occurred, but it can be evidence that a physical change occurred.

C.Choice: The two liquids mix into a solution.

Key.Rationale: Two liquids mixing into a solution is not evidence that a chemical change occurred, but it can be evidence that a physical change occurred.

D.Choice: The two liquids form a new substance.

Key.Rationale: A chemical reaction results in the formation of a new substance with different properties. The two liquids formed small, solid particles, which are a new substance. This is evidence that a chemical reaction occurred

SubTopics: Model and illustrate how the tilted Earth rotates on its axis, causing day and night, and revolves around the Sun, causing changes in seasons.
Use models to represent aspects of the natural world such as an atom, a molecule, space, or a geologic feature.
Content: The diagram shows Earth in its orbit around the sun when very little light is visible at Earth's South Pole.
problems/TX21G8S/media/4a.jpg
Which statement is true when Earth is in the position shown?

F.Choice:
It is August in the Northern Hemisphere.
It is April in the Southern Hemisphere.

Key.Rationale: The months of the year are the same, regardless of the season each hemisphere is experiencing. If it is August in the Northern Hemisphere, it would also be August in the Southern Hemisphere.

G.Choice:
It is summer in the Northern Hemisphere.
It is winter in the Southern Hemisphere.

Key.Rationale: The tilt of Earth's axis causes the seasons because of the angle at which the sunlight strikes Earth's surface. When a pole is tilted toward the sun, there is more direct sunlight on that hemisphere, causing the higher temperatures of summer. In the diagram, it is summer in the Northern Hemisphere and winter in the Southern Hemisphere.

H.Choice: The number of hours of daylight is greater in the Southern Hemisphere than in the Northern Hemisphere.

Key.Rationale: The number of hours of daylight and darkness is determined by how directly sunlight is striking Earth. When a location is tilted away from the sun, that location receives fewer hours of daylight than it does when it is tilted toward the sun. The number of hours of daylight is less, not greater, in the Southern Hemisphere than in the Northern Hemisphere because the Southern Hemisphere is tilted away from the sun.

J.Choice: Spring begins earlier in the year in the Southern Hemisphere than it does in the Northern Hemisphere.

Key.Rationale: The seasons of the year are opposite from one hemisphere to another. In the Northern Hemisphere, spring begins in March, but in the Southern Hemisphere, spring begins in September.

SubTopics: Explore how short- and long-term environmental changes affect organisms and traits in subsequent populations.
Analyze data to formulate reasonable explanations, communicate valid conclusions supported by the data, and predict trends.
Content: Tiny organisms called Daphnia live in lakes and ponds where they consume algae. A lake with a stable population of algae and Daphnia was contaminated by pollution, resulting in the death of many algae.
Which graph shows the most likely trend in the Daphnia population in the lake shortly before and after the pollution event?

A.Choice: problems/TX21G8S/media/5a.jpg

Key.Rationale: This graph shows an increase in the Daphnia population after the pollution event. The pollution event resulted in the death of many algae. This means that the population decreased after the pollution event.
Because the pollution event killed many algae, but not all of them, the Daphnia population would recover once the algae population did.

Pollution resulted in the death of many algae. Because Daphnia consume algae, the population of Daphnia would decrease after the pollution event. Because the pollution event killed many algae but not all, the Daphnia population would recover once the algae population increased.

D.Choice: problems/TX21G8S/media/5d.jpg

Key.Rationale: This graph shows that the Daphnia population decreased, but the population did not recover.

SubTopics: Demonstrate and calculate how unbalanced forces change the speed or direction of an object's motion.

Use appropriate tools, including lab journals/notebooks, beakers, meter sticks, graduated cylinders, anemometers, psychrometers, hot plates, test tubes, spring scales, balances, microscopes, thermometers, calculators, computers, spectroscopes, timing devices, and other necessary equipment to collect, record, and analyze information.
Content: A student pushes a 51.5 kilogram bookshelf across a smooth floor with a net force of 67 N.
What is the approximate acceleration of the bookshelf?

Key.Rationale:
The value 1.3 m/s² was obtained by rearranging the formula Force = mass × acceleration to solve for acceleration.
a = F/m = 67 N/ 51.5 kg = 1.3 m/s
The value 3,425.05 is obtained by multiplying mass and force.
The value 15.5 is obtained by subtracting mass from force.
The value 0.77 is obtained by dividing mass from force.

SubTopics: Interpret topographic maps and satellite views to identify land and erosional features and predict how these features may be reshaped by weathering.
Analyze data to formulate reasonable explanations, communicate valid conclusions supported by the data, and predict trends.
Content: A topographic map provides details about Emory Peak in Big Bend National Park. A radio tower on Emory Peak is indicated.
problems/TX21G8S/media/7a.jpg
Based on the topographic map, if a park ranger hiked due west from the radio tower, the ranger's path would  —

A.Choice: cross a canyon with a river running through it

Key.Rationale: Contour lines crossing a river are bent to form a V that points upstream. Since a river would flow downhill from the peak and the contour lines are not bent to point up the hill, there is no river present.

B.Choice: cross another peak in the park

Key.Rationale: A peak is represented by contour lines arranged in a circle. There are no peaks to the west of the radio tower.

C.Choice: be flat and then go up a steep slope

Key.Rationale: A flat path is represented by contour lines that are far apart. A steep slope is represented by lines that are close together.

D.Choice: go down a steep slope and then become flatter

Key.Rationale: The spacing of the contour lines shows how steep or gentle the slope of the surface is. Contour lines that are close together represent a steep slope. Contour lines that are far apart represent a gentle slope. The contour lines are close together and then become farther apart as the park ranger travels west from the radio tower.

SubTopics: Interpret the arrangement of the Periodic Table, including groups and periods, to explain how properties are used to classify elements.
Content: Which pair of elements are nonmetals and gases at room temperature and normal atmospheric pressure?

Key.Rationale: Fluorine and chlorine are nonmetals that are gases at room temperature.
Boron is a metalloid, and aluminum is a metal.

H.Choice: Hydrogen, H, and cesium, Cs

Key.Rationale: Hydrogen is a nonmetal gas at room temperature, but cesium is a metal that is a solid at room temperature.

J.Choice: Cobalt, Co, and nickel, Ni

Key.Rationale: Cobalt and nickel are metals.

SubTopics: Describe how biodiversity contributes to the sustainability of an ecosystem.

Analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student.
Content: A farmer digs a small pond in a pasture. The farmer adds young individuals from two species of algae-eating fish to the pond and plants some reeds around the edges of the pond. The farmer wants the pond to be a sustainable ecosystem.
Which of the following would be most helpful in increasing the pond ecosystem's sustainability?

A.Choice: Decreasing the number of plant species around the edges of the pond

Key.Rationale: The pond's sustainability would not increase because decreasing the number of plant species anywhere in the pond leads to a decrease in biodiversity.

B.Choice: Introducing older fish of the same species into the population of algae-eating fish

Key.Rationale: Introducing older fish of the same species would not increase the sustainability of the pond because the biodiversity is not increased.

C.Choice: Having a greater diversity of living organisms in the pond

Key.Rationale: Sustainability of an ecosystem comes from having high species diversity within the ecosystem. Having a greater diversity of living organisms in the pond would increase the biodiversity. If the biodiversity of the pond is increased, the sustainability of the pond would increase.

D.Choice: Adding gravel between the water and where the reeds are planted

Key.Rationale: Adding gravel anywhere in the pond would not increase the pond's sustainability because the biodiversity is not increased.

SubTopics: Differentiate between speed, velocity, and acceleration.
Analyze data to formulate reasonable explanations, communicate valid conclusions supported by the data, and predict trends.
Content: A student investigates the motion of a toy vehicle. The student graphs 40 seconds of data from the investigation.
problems/TX21G8S/media/10a.jpg
Which statement best describes the motion of the toy vehicle during the first 30 seconds of the investigation?

F.Choice: The vehicle was traveling at a constant speed.

Key.Rationale: The slope (distance/time) of a distance vs. time graph represents the speed of the object. The graph shows a constant slope, which means the speed is constant.

G.Choice: The vehicle was accelerating at a constant rate.

Key.Rationale: Acceleration refers to a change in speed or direction. The speed is not changing because the slope of the graph is not changing in the first 30 seconds of the investigation.

H.Choice: The speed of the vehicle was increasing.

Key.Rationale: The graph shows a constant slope between 0 and 30 seconds, not an increasing slope.

J.Choice: The acceleration of the vehicle was increasing.

Key.Rationale: The acceleration of the vehicle is not changing. Because the speed is constant, there is no acceleration.

SubTopics: Describe the structure of atoms, including the masses, electrical charges, and locations, of protons and neutrons in the nucleus and electrons in the electron cloud.
Content: How many neutrons are in the nucleus of a potassium atom with a mass number of 39?

Key.Rationale:
The mass number represents the number of protons and neutrons in the nucleus of an atom. The atomic number represents the number of protons in an atom. The mass number for potassium is 39. The atomic number for potassium is 19. To obtain the number of neutrons in the nucleus of an atom, subtract the atomic number from the mass number.
Mass number –– atomic number = number of neutrons.
39 protons and neutrons –– 19 protons = 20 neutrons.

SubTopics: Identify the role of the oceans in the formation of weather systems such as hurricanes.

Analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student.
Content: Major surface currents of the ocean are shown in the diagram.
problems/TX21G8S/media/12a.jpg
Ocean currents affect weather patterns by  —

F.Choice: regulating when tides occur in coastal areas

Key.Rationale: Ocean currents do not control tides. The gravitational pull of the moon on Earth regulates tides.

G.Choice: trapping heat at the equator to regulate the global climate

Key.Rationale: Ocean currents do not trap heat to control the global climate. Ocean currents distribute heat.

H.Choice: distributing heat from the uneven absorption of solar energy

Key.Rationale: Oceans are heated by the sun's energy. Ocean currents transport warm water from the equator toward the poles and cold water from the poles back to the tropics.

J.Choice: increasing the rate of evaporation to transport water to areas experiencing droughts

Key.Rationale: Ocean currents do not choose to travel to areas experiencing drought.

SubTopics: Differentiate between structure and function in plant and animal cell organelles, including cell membrane, cell wall, nucleus, cytoplasm, mitochondrion, chloroplast, and vacuole.
Collect and record data using the International System of Units (SI) and qualitative means such as labeled drawings, writing, and graphic organizers.
Content: Students view two different cells under a microscope. They record their observations in the table shown.
problems/TX21G8S/media/13a.jpg
Based on the organelles observed, the students determine that cell 2 is a plant cell because it has an organelle that  —

A.Choice: allows water to enter and exit the cell

Key.Rationale: Both plant and animal cells store nutrients in vacuoles.
Both plant and animal cells contain genetic information in a nucleus.
Both plant and animal cells allow water to enter and exit the cell through the cell membrane.

D.Choice: produces its own food

Key.Rationale: Plant cells use chloroplasts to obtain energy to produce their own food.

SubTopics: Compare metals, nonmetals, and metalloids using physical properties such as luster, conductivity, or malleability.
Content: Which statements correctly compare metals and nonmetals?

F.Choice:
Metals tend to be good conductors of thermal energy.
Nonmetals tend to be good insulators of thermal energy.

Key.Rationale: Both metals and nonmetals are able to transfer thermal energy; the difference is in the speed of transfer and the degree to which the transfer occurs.

G.Choice:
Metals are dull and brittle.
Nonmetals are shiny and malleable.

Key.Rationale: Nonmetals tend to be dull and brittle. Metals tend to be shiny and malleable.

H.Choice:
Metals are good insulators of electricity.
Nonmetals tend to be good conductors of electricity.

Key.Rationale: Metals tend to be good conductors of electricity.

J.Choice:
Metals cannot be stretched into thin wires.
Nonmetals can be stretched into thin wires.

Key.Rationale: In general, metals can be stretched into thin wires. In general, nonmetals cannot be stretched into thin wires.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast potential and kinetic energy.

Analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student.
Content: Roller coasters are popular attractions at amusement parks. A cart on a roller coaster approaches the highest point on the coaster. As the cart reaches the top, it slows down.
Which statement best describes the energy of the roller coaster as it slows down while traveling to the top of the coaster?

A.Choice: The cart gains both kinetic and potential energy.

Key.Rationale: The cart loses kinetic energy and gains potential energy.

B.Choice: The cart gains kinetic energy and loses potential energy.

Key.Rationale: The cart loses kinetic energy and gains potential energy.

C.Choice: The cart loses kinetic energy and gains potential energy.

Key.Rationale: The amount of kinetic energy an object has depends on its motion and speed. The amount of potential energy an object has depends on its position. As the cart of a roller coaster approaches the highest point, its potential energy increases because it is getting higher above the earth, but its kinetic energy is decreasing because it slows down as it goes up the hill.

D.Choice: The cart loses both kinetic and potential energy.

Key.Rationale: The cart loses kinetic energy and gains potential energy.

SubTopics: Demonstrate and predict the sequence of events in the lunar cycle.
Analyze data to formulate reasonable explanations, communicate valid conclusions supported by the data, and predict trends.
Content: Students recorded the dates in May on which they observed a full moon and a last quarter moon.
problems/TX21G8S/media/16a.jpg
On which date will they most likely be able to observe a new moon?

Key.Rationale: On May 13 there will still be a last quarter moon. Moon phases last about 3–4 days each.
On May 18 there will be a new moon. A new moon would be visible approximately 5–7 days after a last quarter moon.

H.Choice: May 25

Key.Rationale: On May 25 there will be a first quarter moon. A first quarter moon follows a new moon.

J.Choice: May 31

Key.Rationale: On May 31 there will be a full moon. A full moon is visible after a first quarter moon.

SubTopics: Recognize that chemical formulas are used to identify substances and determine the number of atoms of each element in chemical formulas containing subscripts.
Content: The names and chemical formulas of four substances are shown in the chart.
problems/TX21G8S/media/17a.jpg
Which substance listed in the chart is made up of the most atoms?

A.Choice: Carbonic acid

Key.Rationale: The subscript 2 on the symbol for hydrogen, H, indicates that there are 2 hydrogen atoms. There is no subscript on the symbol for carbon, C, so this indicates that there is 1 carbon atom. The subscript 3 on the symbol for oxygen, O, indicates that there are 3 oxygen atoms. The total number of atoms in carbonic acid = 2 hydrogen atoms + 1 carbon atom + 3 oxygen atoms = 7 total atoms.

There is no subscript on the symbol for hydrogen, H, so this indicates that there is 1 hydrogen atom. There is no subscript on the symbol for nitrogen, N, so this indicates that there is 1 nitrogen atom. The subscript 3 on the symbol for oxygen, O, indicates that there are 3 oxygen atoms. The total number of atoms in nitric acid = 1 hydrogen atom + 1 nitrogen atom + 3 oxygen atoms = 5 total atoms.

The subscript 3 on the symbol for hydrogen, H, indicates that there are 3 hydrogen atoms. There is no subscript on the symbol for phosphorus, P, so this indicates that there is 1 phosphorus atom. The subscript 4 on the symbol for oxygen, O, indicates that there are 4 oxygen atoms. The total number of atoms in phosphoric acid = 3 hydrogen atoms + 1 phosphorus atom + 4 oxygen atoms = 8 total atoms.

D.Choice: Sulfuric acid

Key.Rationale: The subscript 2 on the symbol for hydrogen, H, indicates that there are 2 hydrogen atoms. There is no subscript on the symbol for sulfur, S, so this indicates that there is 1 sulfur atom. The subscript 4 on the symbol for oxygen, O, indicates that there are 4 oxygen atoms. The total number of atoms in sulfuric acid = 2 hydrogen atoms + 1 sulfur atom + 4 oxygen atoms = 7 total atoms.

SubTopics: Understand that gravity is the force that governs the motion of our solar system.
Use models to represent aspects of the natural world such as an atom, a molecule, space, or a geologic feature.
Content: An image of the Earth-moon-sun system is shown.
problems/TX21G8S/media/18a.jpg
The moon remains in orbit around Earth because of the force of  —

Key.Rationale: Earth's rotation is not an attractive force. Therefore, Earth's rotation cannot cause the moon to remain in orbit around Earth
The moon's rotation is not an attractive force. Therefore, the moon's rotation cannot cause the moon to remain in orbit around Earth.

H.Choice: Earth's gravity

Key.Rationale: Earth's gravity is the attractive force that causes the moon to remain in orbit around Earth.

J.Choice: the sun's gravity

Key.Rationale: The sun's gravity is an attractive force. The sun's gravity keeps the Earth in orbit around the sun, not the moon around Earth.

SubTopics: Investigate how organisms and populations in an ecosystem depend on and may compete for biotic factors such as food and abiotic factors such as quantity of light, water, range of temperatures, or soil composition.
Analyze data to formulate reasonable explanations, communicate valid conclusions supported by the data, and predict trends.
Content: Three different species of plants that live in the desert are shown.
problems/TX21G8S/media/19a.jpg
Species Z can successfully share the same environment with the other plants shown because species Z absorbs water  —

A.Choice: found deep underground, and species X absorbs water near the soil surface

Key.Rationale: Species Z does not absorb water deep underground because Species Z has short, mostly horizontal roots. Short roots absorb water near the soil surface. Species X absorbs water mostly deep underground because Species X has long, mostly vertical roots.

B.Choice: found deep underground, and species X absorbs water found deep underground

Key.Rationale: Species Z does not absorb water deep underground because Species Z has short, mostly horizontal roots.

C.Choice: near the soil surface, and species Y absorbs water near the soil surface

Key.Rationale: Species Y absorbs water mostly deep underground because Species Y has long, mostly vertical roots.

D.Choice: near the soil surface, and species Y absorbs water found deep underground

Key.Rationale:
Species Z has short, mostly horizontal roots. Short roots absorb water near the soil surface.
Species Y has long, mostly vertical roots. Long roots absorb water deep underground.

SubTopics: Demonstrate and calculate how unbalanced forces change the speed or direction of an object's motion.

Analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student.
Content: The diagram shows a duck swimming in a stream in the opposite direction the stream is flowing. The duck pushes against the water, so the water pushes the duck forward with 20 newtons of force. The water also exerts 15 newtons of resistive force against the duck.
problems/TX21G8S/media/20a.jpg
Which statement best describes the resulting motion of the duck

Key.Rationale: The duck will not stop moving because the duck exerts a net force of 5N to the right.

G.Choice: The duck will stop and then start moving again.

Key.Rationale: The duck will not stop moving because the duck exerts a net force of 5N to the right.

H.Choice: The duck will continue moving in its current direction.

Key.Rationale: Because 20N is greater than 15N, the net force of 5N will cause the duck to move to the right.

J.Choice: The duck will move in the direction that the stream is flowing.

Key.Rationale: The water is exerting 15 newtons of resistive force against the duck. 20 newtons is greater than 15 newtons, so the duck will move in the direction of the 20N force.

SubTopics: Calculate density to identify an unknown substance.
Analyze data to formulate reasonable explanations, communicate valid conclusions supported by the data, and predict trends.
Content: A student measures the mass and volume of a small cube made of an unknown metal. The mass of the cube is 25.0 g, and the volume of the cube is 3.19 cm³. The student is told that the cube is a sample of one of the four metals listed in the table.
problems/TX21G8S/media/21a.jpg
Based on the data given, the unknown metal is most likely  —

A.Choice: gold

Key.Rationale: The density of gold is 19.30 g/cm³. Since the density of the unknown metal is 7.83 g/cm³, the unknown metal is not gold.

The density of the unknown metal was obtained using the equation Density = mass/volume. D = 25.0 g / 3.19 cm³ = 7.83 g/cm³. The density of iron is 7.85 g/cm³. This value is the closest to the density value for the unknown metal. Therefore, the unknown metal is most likely iron.
The density of silver is 10.50 g/cm³. Since the density of the unknown metal is 7.83 g/cm³, the unknown metal is not silver.

D.Choice: tin

Key.Rationale: The density for tin is 7.28 g/cm³. Since the density of the unknown metal is 7.83 g/cm³, the unknown metal is not tin.

SubTopics: Identify how different wavelengths of the electromagnetic spectrum such as visible light and radio waves are used to gain information about components in the universe.

Analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student.
Content: The temperature of a star determines the wavelength of visible light that is produced. The visible part of the electromagnetic spectrum is shown.
problems/TX21G8S/media/22a.jpg
Stars with the highest temperatures will emit most of their light at wavelengths that are near  —

Key.Rationale: Stars that emit most of their visible light at this wavelength are not as hot as stars with a shorter wavelength.
Stars that emit most of their visible light at this wavelength are not as hot as stars with a shorter wavelength.

H.Choice: green light

Key.Rationale: Stars that emit most of their visible light at this wavelength are not as hot as stars with a shorter wavelength.

J.Choice: blue light

Key.Rationale: Stars that emit most of their visible light at wavelengths that are near blue light are the hottest. Stars with the shortest wavelength are the hottest stars.

SubTopics: Explore how short- and long-term environmental changes affect organisms and traits in subsequent populations.
Content: There is a range of beak depths in a population of a certain species of seed-eating bird. Scientists observed the feeding behavior of the seed-eating birds and recorded their observations in the table.
problems/TX21G8S/media/23a.jpg
problems/TX21G8S/media/23b.jpg
Which statement best predicts the change in subsequent populations of these seed-eating birds if the availability of small seeds decreases?

A.Choice: Birds with a large beak depth will require less food in order to survive and reproduce.

Key.Rationale: A change in the availability of a type of seed will not affect how much food a bird requires.

B.Choice: Birds with a large beak depth will have an advantage over birds with a small beak depth and will be better able to survive and reproduce.

Key.Rationale: Larger beaks will be needed to crack open the larger seeds. Birds with smaller beaks will not be able to access the food from the larger seeds.

C.Choice: Birds with a small beak depth will have an advantage over birds with large beak depths and will be better able to survive and reproduce.

Key.Rationale: Birds with a small beak depth will not have an advantage over birds with a large beak depth because larger beaks are needed to crack open larger seeds.

D.Choice: Neither birds with a small beak depth nor birds with a large beak depth will have a reproductive advantage.

Key.Rationale: Birds with a large beak depth will have an advantage because larger beaks are needed to crack open larger seeds

SubTopics: Demonstrate energy transformations such as energy in a flashlight battery changes from chemical energy to electrical energy to light energy.

Use appropriate tools, including lab journals/notebooks, beakers, meter sticks, graduated cylinders, anemometers, psychrometers, hot plates, test tubes, spring scales, balances, microscopes, thermometers, calculators, computers, spectroscopes, timing devices, and other necessary equipment to collect, record, and analyze information.
Content: Students build a circuit. The circuit has wires that connect a battery to a switch and a fan.
Which energy transformations happen when the students close the circuit and the blades of the fan begin to spin?

Key.Rationale: Mechanical energy is not being converted to electrical energy as the blades spin. On the contrary, electrical energy is being converted to mechanical energy as the blades begin to spin.
Electrical energy is not being converted to chemical energy. Instead, chemical energy is converted to electrical energy, which causes the blades to spin.

H.Choice: Chemical to electrical to mechanical

Key.Rationale: Chemical energy is energy stored in chemical bonds. Batteries store chemical energy that can be transformed into electrical energy. Electrical energy is the energy of moving electrons. Mechanical energy is the energy an object has due to its motion (kinetic energy) or its position (potential energy). Mechanical energy is used to spin the blades of the fan.

J.Choice: Mechanical to electrical to chemical

Key.Rationale: Mechanical energy is not being converted to electrical energy, and electrical energy is not being converted to chemical energy. This order is reversed.

SubTopics: Distinguish between physical and chemical changes in matter.

Analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student.
Content: Students create a table that lists processes observed in nature.
problems/TX21G8S/media/25a.jpg
Which process describes only a physical change?

A.Choice: Process 1

Key.Rationale: Fungus decomposing organic matter results in a new substance and is therefore a chemical change.
Leaves using carbon dioxide to make sugar results in a new substance and is therefore a chemical change.
Plants using nitrogen to make protein results in a new substance and is therefore a chemical change.

D.Choice: Process 4

Key.Rationale: A chemical change results in the formation of a new substance with different chemical properties. A physical change does not form substances with different chemical properties. Although the outward appearance of a substance is changed, the chemical composition remains unchanged. Water evaporating from salt water does not form substances with different chemical properties and is therefore a physical change.

SubTopics: Examine organisms or their structures such as insects or leaves and use dichotomous keys for identification.
Collect and record data using the International System of Units (SI) and qualitative means such as labeled drawings, writing, and graphic organizers.
Content: The diagram shows a wildflower and a dichotomous key that can be used to identify the wildflower.
problems/TX21G8S/media/26a.jpg
problems/TX21G8S/media/26b.jpg
Based on the key, what is the name of this wildflower?

Key.Rationale:
Starflower does not have these characteristics:
1b. Flower has five petals.
2b. Petals appear smooth, in a single piece.
3a. Petals are very long, narrow, and pointed.

Chickweed does not have these characteristics:
2b. Petals appear smooth, in a single piece.

H.Choice: Bowman's root

Key.Rationale:
Bowman's root has these characteristics:
1b. Flower has five petals.
2b. Petals appear smooth, in a single piece.
3a. Petals are very long, narrow, and pointed.

J.Choice: Common strawberry

Key.Rationale:
Common strawberry does not have these characteristics:
3a. Petals are very long, narrow, and pointed.

SubTopics: Describe components of the universe, including stars, nebulae, and galaxies, and use models such as the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram for classification.
Use models to represent aspects of the natural world such as an atom, a molecule, space, or a geologic feature.
Content: The Hertzsprung-Russell diagram shown is divided into four sections.
problems/TX21G8S/media/27a.jpg
Which section of the diagram includes the coolest, brightest stars?

A.Choice: Section 1

Key.Rationale: The stars in section 1 are the hottest and brightest stars. The stars in section 1 have a temperature range of 400 x 10² to 75 x 102, and a luminosity range of 10 to 106.

The stars in section 2 are the coolest and brightest stars. According to the H-R diagram, the stars in section 2 have the lowest temperature values and the highest luminosity values. The stars in section two have a temperature range of 75 x 10² K to 30 x 10 2 K and a luminosity range of 10 to 106.
The stars in section 3 are the hottest and dimmest stars. The stars in section 3 have a temperature range of 400 x 102 to 75 x 10², and a luminosity range of 10⁻⁴ to 10.

D.Choice: Section 4

Key.Rationale: The stars in section 4 are the coolest and dimmest stars. The stars in section 3 have a temperature range of 75 x 10² K to 30 x 10 2 K and a luminosity range of 10–4 to 100.

SubTopics: Investigate and describe applications of Newton's three laws of motion such as in vehicle restraints, sports activities, amusement park rides, Earth's tectonic activities, and rocket launches.
Content: A skater pushes off a wall and skates backward for a few meters before stopping.
problems/TX21G8S/media/28a.jpg
Which statement best describes an action–reaction force pair in this situation?

F.Choice: The wall pushes on the skater when the skater pushes on the wall.

Key.Rationale: When two objects interact with each other, those two objects are exerting forces upon each other. The forces that the interacting objects exert on each other are called action and reaction forces. The action force is the force applied by the first object (the skater) on the second object (the wall). The reaction force is the force applied by the second object (the wall) on the first object (the skater). Action-reaction pairs are equal yet opposite in direction.

G.Choice: The wheels slow down, and the skater stops.

Key.Rationale: This interaction is not an action-reaction pair. This interaction is an example of friction. Friction would cause the wheels to slow down, which, in turn, causes the skater to eventually stop.

H.Choice: The skater exerts a force on the wall, and the wheels exert a force on the floor and begin to turn.

Key.Rationale: This interaction is not an action-reaction pair. An action-reaction pair occurs between two objects. An example of an action-reaction pair is the wheels exerting a force on the floor and the floor exerting a force on the wheels.

J.Choice: The friction of the floor decreases when the wheels roll on the floor.

Key.Rationale: This interaction is not an action-reaction pair. Friction contributes to changes in acceleration and velocity.

SubTopics: Diagram the flow of energy through living systems, including food chains, food webs, and energy pyramids.
Use models to represent aspects of the natural world such as an atom, a molecule, space, or a geologic feature.
Content: Fox squirrels are common in Texas. Fox squirrels primarily eat acorns and nuts from trees but also eat insects. Some predators of fox squirrels include owls, snakes, and bobcats.
Which diagram best represents how energy would flow to and from the fox squirrel?

A.Choice: problems/TX21G8S/media/29a.jpg

Key.Rationale: The energy does not flow from fox squirrels to acorns and nuts because acorns and nuts do not eat fox squirrels. Instead, the energy flows from acorns and nuts to fox squirrels because fox squirrels eat acorns and nuts.

The energy does not flow from fox squirrels to acorns and nuts because acorns and nuts do not eat fox squirrels. Instead, the energy flows from acorns and nuts to fox squirrels because fox squirrels eat acorns and nuts. The energy does not flow from the bobcats, snakes, and owls to fox squirrels because fox squirrels do not eat bobcats, snakes, and owls. Instead, the energy flows from fox squirrels to bobcats, snakes, and owls because bobcats, snakes, and owls eat fox squirrels.

The arrows in a food web represent the direction of energy flow. In this food web, energy flows from acorns, insects, and nuts to fox squirrels because fox squirrels eat acorns, insects, and nuts. The energy flows from fox squirrels to bobcats, snakes, and owls because bobcats, snakes, and owls are predators of fox squirrels.

D.Choice: problems/TX21G8S/media/29d.jpg

Key.Rationale: ll the arrows are reversed. Therefore, the energy flow is reversed for all organisms in this food web.

SubTopics: Identify the main functions of the systems of the human organism, including the circulatory, respiratory, skeletal, muscular, digestive, excretory, reproductive, integumentary, nervous, and endocrine systems.
Content: Which two body systems are primarily responsible for locomotion?

Key.Rationale: The human skeletal system provides structure and support for the body. The muscular system connects to the skeletal system, which allows for movement.

The nervous system transmits messages and controls body functions. The circulatory system transports nutrients and oxygen to cells throughout the body and transports carbon dioxide and waste products away from the body.

H.Choice: Respiratory system and digestive system

Key.Rationale: The respiratory system delivers oxygen to the cells and removes carbon dioxide from the circulatory system. The digestive system ingests food, breaks down the food, and processes the nutrients from the food.

J.Choice: Integumentary system and excretory system

Key.Rationale: The integumentary system protects against disease, creates a barrier against outside environments, protects internal organs, and regulates body temperature. The excretory system removes waste products from the body.

SubTopics: Relate the positions of the Moon and Sun to their effect on ocean tides.
Use models to represent aspects of the natural world such as an atom, a molecule, space, or a geologic feature.
Content: The diagram models four lunar phases.
problems/TX21G8S/media/31a.jpg
During which lunar phase is the tide highest?

A.Choice: Phase 1

Key.Rationale: This is an image of a first quarter moon. The tide is very small during a first quarter moon. Neap tides occur during the first or third quarter moon. Neap tides are when the difference between high and low tides is the least. During the first and third quarter moon, the pull of the moon's gravity is at a right angle to the pull of the sun's gravity, so the tide is at its lowest.
This is an image of a waxing crescent. The tide is small during a waxing crescent.

This is an image of a new moon. A tide is the periodic rising and falling of the ocean surface. The rise and fall of the oceans are caused by the gravitational interaction between Earth, the moon, and the sun. High tides and low tides occur every day. Spring tides are when there is the biggest difference between high and low tide. During spring tides, the high tide is highest and the low tide is lowest. Spring tides occur during a new and full moon when the Earth, the moon, and the sun are aligned. The pull of the sun's gravity and the moon's gravity are in line with each other.

D.Choice: Phase 4

Key.Rationale: This is an image of a third quarter moon. The tide is very small during a third quarter moon. Neap tides occur during the first or third quarter moon. Neap tides are when the difference between high and low tides is the least. During the first and third quarter moon, the pull of the moon's gravity is at a right angle to the pull of the sun's gravity, so the tide is at its lowest.

SubTopics: Calculate average speed using distance and time measurements.
Content: A horse trainer records the distance a horse travels during three different trials.
problems/TX21G8S/media/32a.jpg
What is the horse's average speed in kilometers per minute?

Key.Rationale:
The average speed for each trial was obtained by using the equation Speed = distance/time. The units used are kilometers, km, per minute, min.
The average speed for Trial 1 is S = d/t = 4.5 km/15 min = 0.3 km/min.
The average speed for Trial 2 is S = d/t = 9.0 km/30 min = 0.3 km/min.
The average speed for Trial 3 is S = d/t = 13.5 km/45 min = 0.3 km/min.
The average speed for all trials was obtained by using the equation Average = sum of the data/sample size.
The average of the speed for all trials is
(0.3 km/min + 0.3 km/min + 0.3 km/min)/3 = 0.9 km/min/3 = 0.3 km/min.

SubTopics: Recognize the components of cell theory.

Analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student.
Content: Which statement best describes cell theory?

A.Choice: Cells are part of complex organisms that work together to produce new cells.

Key.Rationale: This is not a component of cell theory.

B.Choice: Cells perform a single life function, and most cells come from existing cells.

Key.Rationale: Many cells perform several life functions. All cells, not most, come from existing cells.

C.Choice: Cells use energy from food to be able to perform life functions and work together to produce new cells.

Key.Rationale: Cells are the basic unit of life for all organisms, not the basic unit of structure.

D.Choice: Cells are the basic unit of structure for all organisms, and all cells come from existing cells.

Key.Rationale:
The components of the cell theory are:
1. All living organisms are made up of cells.
2. Cells are the basic unit of life.
3. All cells come from preexisting cells.

SubTopics: Describe the historical development of evidence that supports plate tectonic theory.

Analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student.
Content: This picture shows scratches in bedrock that were caused by a moving glacier. These scratches are called glacial striations.
problems/TX21G8S/media/34a.jpg
Glacial striations in the bedrock of South Africa indicate that glaciers once moved across the African continent. The presence of glaciers on the surface of Africa is evidence that  —

F.Choice: the tectonic plate under Africa was closer to the South Pole at one time

Key.Rationale: There are no glaciers present in Africa at this time. In order for Africa to have scratches made by a glacier, Africa had to have been closer to the South Pole.

G.Choice: the equator was not always where it is currently located

Key.Rationale: The equator is an imaginary line that divides the Northern Hemisphere and the Southern Hemisphere. The equator has not changed locations.

H.Choice: volcanoes did not exist until after faults occurred in Earth's crust

Key.Rationale: Volcanoes are formed when tectonic plates move away from each other or when tectonic plates collide. The formation of glaciers is not related to the formation of volcanoes.

J.Choice: the location of the North Pole and the South Pole changed

Key.Rationale: The North Pole and the South Pole have reversed in polarity many times in Earth's history. Evidence of this is found on some rocks in the ocean floor, not in the presence of glaciers.

SubTopics: Identify that protons determine an element's identity and valence electrons determine its chemical properties, including reactivity.
Analyze data to formulate reasonable explanations, communicate valid conclusions supported by the data, and predict trends.
Content: Which pair of elements has reactivity that is similar to chlorine, Cl?

A.Choice: Fluorine, F, and argon, Ar

Key.Rationale: Argon, Ar, is in Group 18. Therefore, argon has 8 valence electrons. An element with 8 valence electrons will have reactivity that is similar to other elements that have 8 valence electrons. Since chlorine has 7 valence electrons, their reactivities are not similar.

Chlorine, Cl, is in Group 17. All elements in Group 17 have 7 valence electrons. Valence electrons, located in the outermost energy level of an electron cloud, determine the chemical properties of an element. Reactivity, which refers to the ability of an element to react with other elements, is a chemical property. Fluorine, F, and iodine, I, have 7 valence electrons. Because these elements have 7 valence electrons, these elements are in Group 17. Chlorine is also in Group 17; therefore, fluorine and iodine both have reactivities that are similar to chlorine.

Sulfur, S, is in Group 16. Therefore, sulfur has 6 valence electrons. Bromine, Br, is in Group 2. Therefore, bromine has 2 valence electrons. Since chlorine has 7 valence electrons, its reactivity is not similar to either sulfur or bromine.

D.Choice: Sulfur, S, and argon, Ar

Key.Rationale: Sulfur and argon have a different number of valence electrons than chlorine has. Therefore, sulfur and argon have different reactivities than chlorine.

SubTopics: Investigate how organisms and populations in an ecosystem depend on and may compete for biotic factors such as food and abiotic factors such as quantity of light, water, range of temperatures, or soil composition.

Analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student.
Content: Plants that live on the floors of densely populated forests must compete for sunlight. Which type of leaves are most likely found on plants that are best suited to living on the floor of a dense forest?

Key.Rationale: Leaves that are needle-shaped have a small amount of surface area. A leaf with a small amount of surface area cannot absorb as much sunlight as a leaf with a large amount of surface area.
Leaves that are the smallest have a small amount of surface area. A leaf with a small amount of surface area cannot absorb as much sunlight as a leaf with a large amount of surface area.

H.Choice: Leaves that store the greatest amount of water

Key.Rationale: Leaves that store the greatest amount of water do not necessarily allow the plant to compete for sunlight. A large surface area is needed for the leaf to compete for sunlight.

J.Choice: Leaves with the greatest amount of surface area

Key.Rationale: Leaves with the greatest amount of surface area allow for the greatest amount of sunlight to be absorbed.

SubTopics: Investigate how evidence of chemical reactions indicates that new substances with different properties are formed and how that relates to the law of conservation of mass.
Analyze data to formulate reasonable explanations, communicate valid conclusions supported by the data, and predict trends.
Content: Two solutions are mixed and react to produce the solid precipitate AgCl. The chemical reaction is shown by the balanced chemical equation.
AgNO₃ + NaCl ⇒ AgCl + NaNO₃
What happens to the total mass as the reaction takes place?

A.Choice: The mass increases.

Key.Rationale: The mass will not increase. The mass will remain the same before and after the chemical reaction occurs.
The mass will not decrease. The mass will remain the same before and after the chemical reaction occurs.

According to the law of conservation of mass, mass is not created or destroyed in a chemical reaction. The total mass is conserved, which means that the amount of mass remains the same before and after a chemical reaction occurs.

D.Choice: The mass first decreases and then increases.

Key.Rationale: The mass will not decrease nor increase. The mass will remain the same before and after the chemical reaction occurs.

SubTopics: Model and illustrate how the tilted Earth rotates on its axis, causing day and night, and revolves around the Sun, causing changes in seasons.
Use models to represent aspects of the natural world such as an atom, a molecule, space, or a geologic feature.
Content: Students make a model using a globe and a flashlight.
problems/TX21G8S/media/38a.jpg
Which answer choice best explains the change from daytime to nighttime on Earth?

F.Choice: The sun stops sending light to Earth at night.

Key.Rationale: The sun does not stop sending light to Earth at night.

G.Choice: Earth moves farther away from the sun at night.

Key.Rationale: Earth does not move farther away from the sun at night.

H.Choice: The tilt of Earth causes less light to reach Earth at night.

Key.Rationale: The tilt of Earth causes less light to reach Earth all the time the Earth is tilted away from the sun, not just at night.

J.Choice: Earth rotates and causes different parts of Earth to experience night.

Key.Rationale: Earth rotates on its axis, an imaginary line running through the center of Earth from the North Pole to the South Pole. This causes day and night because different parts of Earth are illuminated by the sun while Earth rotates.

SubTopics: Demonstrate and calculate how unbalanced forces change the speed or direction of an object's motion.
Content: A toy truck is at rest on the floor. Which statement describes the forces acting on the toy truck?

A.Choice: The forces are balanced so motion occurs.

Key.Rationale: When the forces are balanced, no motion occurs.

B.Choice: The forces are balanced so no motion occurs.

Key.Rationale: There are two primary forces acting on the toy truck. The primary forces acting on the toy truck are the toy truck's weight due to gravity and the force of the floor on the toy truck. Both of these forces are balanced. As a result, the truck is at rest, or motionless.

C.Choice: The forces are unbalanced so motion occurs.

Key.Rationale: When the forces are unbalanced, motion occurs.

D.Choice: The forces are unbalanced so no motion occurs.

Key.Rationale: The truck is at rest, so it is motionless. It is motionless because the forces are balanced.

SubTopics: Interpret the arrangement of the Periodic Table, including groups and periods, to explain how properties are used to classify elements.
Analyze data to formulate reasonable explanations, communicate valid conclusions supported by the data, and predict trends.
Content: One of the properties that makes copper, Cu, useful for household wiring is its ability to conduct electricity. Which other element is most likely to conduct electricity?

Key.Rationale: Copper is a metal. Metals are generally good conductors of electricity. Gold is also a metal, so gold is also generally a good conductor of electricity.
Radon is a nonmetal. Nonmetals generally do not conduct electricity.

H.Choice: Bromine, Br

Key.Rationale: Bromine is a nonmetal. Nonmetals generally do not conduct electricity.

J.Choice: Nitrogen, N

Key.Rationale: Nitrogen is a nonmetal. Nonmetals generally do not conduct electricity.

SubTopics: Explore how short- and long-term environmental changes affect organisms and traits in subsequent populations.
Analyze data to formulate reasonable explanations, communicate valid conclusions supported by the data, and predict trends.
Content: Parus major is a bird species that depends on caterpillars as a food source for its young. Caterpillars are most abundant during spring. The yearly increase in temperatures during springtime has gradually shifted, resulting in caterpillars developing approximately two weeks earlier than in the past.
How will the changes in the availability of caterpillars most likely affect future populations of P. major?

A.Choice: P. major will change their food source to plant leaves.

Key.Rationale: P. major cannot immediately change food sources.

B.Choice: P. major will lay their eggs earlier in the year.

Key.Rationale: Since temperature changes are causing caterpillars to develop approximately two weeks earlier, birds that are able to produce eggs earlier so they can rear young while caterpillars are available will have higher reproductive success than birds that cannot.

C.Choice: P. major will decrease the number of eggs laid at a time.

Key.Rationale: P. major cannot choose how many eggs are laid.

D.Choice: P. major will hunt caterpillars earlier in the day when temperatures are cooler.

Key.Rationale: The caterpillars are developing two weeks earlier. Hunting caterpillars earlier during the day when the temperature is cooler will have no effect on the abundance of caterpillars available.

SubTopics: Interpret topographic maps and satellite views to identify land and erosional features and predict how these features may be reshaped by weathering.
Analyze data to formulate reasonable explanations, communicate valid conclusions supported by the data, and predict trends.
Content: The satellite photograph shows geological features, including a glacier.
problems/TX21G8S/media/42a.jpg
As the glacier melts, water travels toward the ocean along the geological feature labeled X. When water erodes soil along this feature, the feature will most likely become  —

Key.Rationale: The geological feature labeled X is a body of water, such as a river. The water travels along this path but does not straighten the path.

The geological feature labeled X is a body of water, such as a river. Water eroding soil along this feature will not make the feature dry. The presence of water prevents this feature from becoming dry.

H.Choice: shorter

Key.Rationale: The geological feature labeled X is a body of water, such as a river. The water travels along this path but does not shorten the path.

J.Choice: wider

Key.Rationale: The geological feature labeled X is a body of water, such as a river. The geological feature becomes wider because the soil is being carried away by the water.
